PC1: Able to demonstrate basic computer organization and components of the computer. Role of system S/W's and CO. Design and Development of Reprogramable Computer.
PC2: Able to explain the  Design of the CPU:-  Instructions & its addressing modes; Floating point operations; design of ALU; data path; control unit; pipelining . RISC vs CISC & ARM architure and prog.
PC3: Able to compare performance of cache memory; compare caches with different configuration; virtual memory and its techniques . Interrupts and its implemenation with in the application.
PC4: Able to simulate and compare performance of cache memory; compare caches with different configulation

PC1: Able to read; interpret and write some basic mathematical notations.
PC2: Able to recognize and to construct examples of mathematical objects introduced during the course such as the sets  and functions.
PC3: Able to several matematical models.
PC4: Able to develop the problem-solving skills.

PC1: Able to demonstrate understanding of Java by implementing relatively large programs.
PC2: Able to discuss object oriented paradigm.
PC3: Able to analyze the problem in terms of use cases and create object oriented design for it.  Able to present the design in UML or other related tools.
PC4: Able to apply pattern oriented program design and implement using design patterns.
PC5: Able to carry out unit testing and test driven development.

PC1: Able to define and discuss the meta-issues concerning knowledge and critically reflect on them
PC2: Able to demonstrate knowledge of diverse traditions in epistemology
PC3: Able to explain specific arguments; methodologies; and approaches to questions of knowledge.
PC4: Able to explain the role of knowledge producers in information society.

PC1: Able to explain concepts of General Psychology
PC2: Able to explain and demonstrate the concepts of cognitive psychology.
PC3: Able to exlain the history and schools of Psychology.
PC4: Able to explain and share experiences on practice of mindfulness.
PC5: Able to demonstrate and explain therapies like Cognitive behavior Therapy practically use it.

PC1: Able to describe Biographies and Techniquesproposed by Theatre Masters.
PC2: Able to demonstrate their theatre communication skills
PC3: Able to put up a mime show

PC1: Able to demonstrate the knowledge of  the quarrel between literature and philosophy
PC2: Able to explain different philosophical theories of literature
PC3: Able to explain some of the intersections between philosophy and literature; including  philosophy and mythology; the problem of evil; theories of social justice; existentialist writing and more
PC4: Able to explain some of the more significant philosophical and literary texts that deal with the interface between philosophy and literature

PC1: Able to apply concepts of continuity; differentiability; extrema and integrability of multivariable functions and evaluate various integrals (line; double; triple and surface integrals).
PC2: Able to work with vector fields; evaluate line and surface integrals; calculate quantities such as work; circulation and flux across plane curves and surfaces; be able to carry out vector derivative operations such as gradient; divergence and curl and understand and apply Green's; Stoke's and divergence  theorems.
PC3: Able to evaluate derivatives and integrals of complex functions; including the applications of Cauchy's theorem.
PC4: Able to determine convergence of complex series and power series and understand and apply Taylor series to represent complex functions.

PC1: Able to classify basic signal representation; continuous time and discrete-time signals
PC2: Able to determine the response of an LTI system to continuous-time or discrete-time input signals.
PC3: Able to represent both continuous-time and discrete-time periodic signals as Fourier series.
PC4: Able toanalyze continuous-time signals and systems using Fourier transform and Laplace transform.
PC5: Able to analyze discrete-time signals and systems using discrete-time Fourier transform and Z-transform.

PC1: Students are familiar with the real number system; can determine convergence-divergence of sequences and series; and are able to construct epsilon-delta proofs related to limits and continuity.
PC2: Students are familiar with the concepts of differentiation and integration and are able to apply the methods of single-variable calculus.
PC3: Students are able to apply concepts of continuity; differentiability; extrema and integrability of multivariable functions and evaluate various integrals (line; double; triple and surface integrals).

PC1: To be able to write down formal Mathematical proofs
PC2: To be able to explain elementary results on distributions of prime numbers
PC3: To be able to apply number-theoretic techniques to simply computations.
PC4: To be able to describe properties of some special number-theorectic functions and their growth rates
PC5: To be able to explain properties of numbers of some special forms
PC6: To be able to describe complete solutions of some special Diophantine equations and to be able to explain insolvability of some special non-linear Diophantine equations
PC7: To be able to explain the proof of Lagrange's four squares theorem
PC8: To be able to explain basic theory of partitions

PC1: Students are able to read and comprehend and present on Key Concepts in social science material.
PC2: Students are able to make cross-disciplinary connections between the sphere of 'economics'۪ and social facts and to conceptualise the links between the Economy and Indian society in particular.
PC3: Students are able to imbibe a value-based; regulatory perspective as a corrective to the competitive self-interest and profit focus of the global economy today.

PC1: This course will help learners appreciate the importance of small but thick data and will hence complement the big data analytics approach; thus enabling the learner to scale between choosing different research techniques in the long term.
PC2: Through an introduction to ethnographic case studies; the learner will be encouraged to apply and incorporate ideas of correlating significant but seemingly tiny clues to a larger canvas.
PC3: The learner would be able to apply basic Digital ethnographic research in a systematic format.
PC4: The learner will be able to present team work to an audience in a creative and easily accessible format.

Course Name: Introduction to Media In Society : A Public Sphere Approach
PC1: Students are introduced to the key theories of the press including the debate on 'public sphere'۪ and 'counter publics'۪; as well as the research fields of media'۪s 'agenda setting' and 'framing'۪
PC2: Students are introduced to the first Theme 1 of 'Media and globalisation'۪; taking up themes of environment; post-nationalism and migrations related case studies
PC3: Students are introduced to Theme 2: Media and Civic participation. Taking up three related themes of Citizen journalism; crowd sourcing and Hacktivism

PC1: Understand concepts in Social informatics
PC2: Identify dominant theories in social informatics
PC3: Understand how social and technologies mutually shape each other
PC4: Apply concepts and theories to analysis real world situations
PC5: Understand how policies often shape polices and rules around technology development deployment and use

PC1: Students are able to discuss the Sanskrit origins of poetry in India.
PC2: Students are able to discuss evolution of Hindi and Urdu along with the poetry (and literature in the two languages)
PC3: Students are able to analyse Indian English poetry; its characteristics and major poets from this phase.

PC1: Students are able to design and implement combinational circuits on FPGA
PC2: Students are able to design and implement sequential circuits on FPGA
PC3: Students are able to write Verilog codes and testbenches to integrate on-board FPGA switches; leds; displays etc.
PC4: Students are able to explain the Zynq SoC architecture and its applications

PC1: Students are be able to analyze moderately complex electrical circuits
PC2: Students are able to synthesize simple electrical circuits (RLCs).
PC3: Students are able to find circuit response using Laplace transform.
PC4: Students are able to explain signal superposition and Fourier transform.
PC5: Students are able to use industry standard SPICE tools for simple circuit analysis.

PC1: Ability to understand and express ideas in a precise mathematical language.
PC2: Ability to come up with and write proofs via various proof techniques such as direct; contrapositive; contradiction; and induction.
PC3: Understand discrete structures such as graphs and basic combinatorial identities such as the binomial coefficients; the factorial function; etc. and their applications in counting discrete structures.
PC4: Be introduced to basic applications of discrete structures in computer science and mathematics.

PC1: Ability to analyze the impact of computer architecture and OS policies on program execution and fine tune the program to run efficiently on a given system.
PC2: Ability to utilize the memory architecture and cache organization of the given computer architecture
PC3: Ability to understand fundamental principles and approaches behind process synchronizations; deadlock avoidance; memory management etc.
